trans-unit.target: Una lista de rostros.Cada elemento de la lista debe ser un nombre de cara o una cara annima.Esto especifica una cara que es un agregado de los atributos de cada una de las caras de la lista.Las caras que aparecen antes en la lista tienen mayor prioridad.

trans-unit.source: A list of four integers (high low micro pico), where 0≤low<65536, 0≤micro<1000000, and 0≤pico<1000000. This represents the number of seconds using the formula: high * 2**16 + low + micro * 10**-6 + pico * 10**-12. In some cases, functions may default to returning two- or three-element lists, with omitted micro and pico components defaulting to zero. On all current machines pico is a multiple of 1000, but this may change as higher-resolution clocks become available.
trans-unit.target: Una lista de cuatro números enteros (high low micro pico) , donde 0≤ low <65536, 0≤ micro <1000000 y 0≤ pico <1000000. Esto representa el número de segundos usando la fórmula: high * 2 ** 16 + low + micro * 10 ** - 6 + pico * 10 ** - 12. En algunos casos, las funciones pueden devolver por defecto listas de dos o tres elementos, con micro y pico componentes omitidos por defecto a cero. En todas las máquinas actuales, pico es un múltiplo de 1000, pero esto puede cambiar a medida que estén disponibles relojes de mayor resolución.

trans-unit.source: A list of functions for write-region to call. Each function in the list is called with two arguments: the start and end of the region to be written. These functions should not alter the contents of the buffer. Instead, they should return annotations.
trans-unit.target: Una lista de funciones para que write-region de escritura llame. Cada función de la lista se llama con dos argumentos: el inicio y el final de la región que se va a escribir. Estas funciones no deben alterar el contenido del búfer. En cambio, deberían devolver anotaciones.

trans-unit.source: A list of functions to be called before playing a sound. Each function is called with one argument, a property list that describes the sound.
trans-unit.target: Una lista de funciones a las que se debe llamar antes de reproducir un sonido.Cada funcin se llama con un argumento,una lista de propiedades que describe el sonido.

trans-unit.source: A list of one element, which is an integer. This form of prefix argument results from one or a succession of
trans-unit.target: Una lista de un elemento,que es un entero.Esta forma de argumento de prefijo resulta de una o una sucesin de

trans-unit.source: A list of other packages (possibly including minimal acceptable version numbers) on which this package depends. The list may be empty, meaning this package has no dependencies. Otherwise, installing this package also automatically installs its dependencies, recursively; if any dependency cannot be found, the package cannot be installed.
trans-unit.target: Una lista de otros paquetes (posiblemente incluyendo los nmeros de versin mnimos aceptables)de los que depende este paquete.La lista puede estar vaca,lo que significa que este paquete no tiene dependencias.De lo contrario,al instalar este paquete tambin se instalan automticamente sus dependencias,de forma recursiva;si no se puede encontrar alguna dependencia,el paquete no se puede instalar.

trans-unit.source: A list of paired elements.
trans-unit.target: Una lista de elementos emparejados.

trans-unit.source: A list of symbols, specifying the font backends to use for drawing characters on the frame, in order of priority. In Emacs built without Cairo drawing on X, there are currently three potentially available font backends: x (the X core font driver), xft (the Xft font driver), and xfthb (the Xft font driver with HarfBuzz text shaping). If built with Cairo drawing, there are also three potentially available font backends on X: x, ftcr (the FreeType font driver on Cairo), and ftcrhb (the FreeType font driver on Cairo with HarfBuzz text shaping). When Emacs is built with HarfBuzz, the default font driver is ftcrhb, although use of the ftcr driver is still possible, but not recommended. On MS-Windows, there are currently three available font backends: gdi (the core MS-Windows font driver), uniscribe (font driver for OTF and TTF fonts with text shaping by the Uniscribe engine), and harfbuzz (font driver for OTF and TTF fonts with HarfBuzz text shaping) (see Windows Fonts in
trans-unit.target: Una lista de símbolos, que especifica los backends de fuente que se utilizarán para dibujar caracteres en el marco, en orden de prioridad. En Emacs construido sin Cairo dibujando en X, actualmente hay tres backends de fuentes potencialmente disponibles: x (el controlador de fuentes del núcleo X), xft (el controlador de fuentes Xft) y xfthb (el controlador de fuentes Xft con forma de texto HarfBuzz). Si se crea con el dibujo de Cairo, también hay tres backends de fuente potencialmente disponibles en X: x , ftcr (el controlador de fuente FreeType en Cairo) y ftcrhb (el controlador de fuente FreeType en Cairo con forma de texto HarfBuzz). Cuando Emacs se construye con HarfBuzz, el controlador de fuente predeterminado es ftcrhb , aunque el uso del ftcr controlador ftcr todavía es posible, pero no se recomienda. En MS-Windows, actualmente hay tres backends de fuente disponibles: gdi (el controlador de fuente principal de MS-Windows), uniscribe (controlador de fuente para fuentes OTF y TTF con modelado de texto por el motor Uniscribe) y harfbuzz (controlador de fuente para OTF y Fuentes TTF con forma de texto HarfBuzz) (consulte Fuentes de Windows en

trans-unit.source: A list of terminal parameters. See Terminal Parameters.
trans-unit.target: Una lista de parámetros del terminal. Consulte Parámetros de terminal .

trans-unit.source: A list whose first element is a string or list means to process all the elements recursively and concatenate the results. This is the most common form of mode line construct.
trans-unit.target: Una lista cuyo primer elemento es una cadena o lista significa procesar todos los elementos de forma recursiva y concatenar los resultados.Esta es la forma ms comn de construccin de lnea de modo.

trans-unit.source: A list whose first element is a symbol representing the font type, one of x, opentype, truetype, type1, pcf, or bdf. For OpenType fonts, the list includes 2 additional elements describing the GSUB and GPOS features supported by the font. Each of these elements is a list of the form ((script (langsys feature …) …) …), where script is a symbol representing an OpenType script tag, langsys is a symbol representing an OpenType langsys tag (or nil, which stands for the default langsys), and each feature is a symbol representing an OpenType feature tag.
trans-unit.target: Una lista cuyo primer elemento es un símbolo que representa el tipo de fuente, uno de x , opentype , truetype , type1 , pcf o bdf . Para las fuentes OpenType, la lista incluye 2 elementos adicionales que describen las características GSUB y GPOS compatibles con la fuente. Cada uno de estos elementos es una lista del formulario ((script (langsys feature …) …) …) , donde script es un símbolo que representa una etiqueta de script OpenType, langsys es un símbolo que representa una etiqueta langsys OpenType (o nil , que significa langsys predeterminado), y cada feature es un símbolo que representa una etiqueta de característica OpenType.

trans-unit.source: A list whose first element is a symbol that is not a keyword specifies a conditional. Its meaning depends on the value of symbol. If symbol has a non-nil value, the second element, then, is processed recursively as a mode line construct. Otherwise, the third element, else, is processed recursively. You may omit else; then the mode line construct displays nothing if the value of symbol is nil or void.
trans-unit.target: Una lista cuyo primer elemento es un símbolo que no es una palabra clave especifica un condicional. Su significado depende del valor del symbol . Si el symbol tiene un valor distinto de nil , el segundo elemento, then , se procesa de forma recursiva como una construcción de línea de modo. De lo contrario, el tercer elemento, en caso else , se procesa de forma recursiva. Puede omitir else ; entonces la construcción de la línea de modo no muestra nada si el valor del symbol es nil o nulo.

trans-unit.source: A list whose first element is an integer specifies truncation or padding of the results of <var>rest</var>. The remaining elements <var>rest</var> are processed recursively as mode line constructs and concatenated together. When <var>width</var> is positive, the result is space filled on the right if its width is less than <var>width</var>. When <var>width</var> is negative, the result is truncated on the right to -<var>width</var> columns if its width exceeds -<var>width</var>.
trans-unit.target: Una lista cuyo primer elemento es un número entero especifica el truncamiento o relleno de los resultados del <var>rest</var> o . El resto de elementos <var>rest</var> antes se procesan recursivamente como construcciones de línea de modo y se concatenan juntos. Cuando el <var>width</var> es positivo, el resultado es un espacio relleno a la derecha si su ancho es menor que el <var>width</var> . Cuando el <var>width</var> es negativo, el resultado se trunca en las columnas de derecha a <var>width</var> si su ancho excede el <var>width</var> .

trans-unit.source: A list whose first element is the symbol :eval says to evaluate form, and use the result as a string to display. Make sure this evaluation cannot load any files, as doing so could cause infinite recursion.
trans-unit.target: Una lista cuyo primer elemento es el símbolo :eval dice que evalúe la form a y use el resultado como una cadena para mostrar. Asegúrese de que esta evaluación no pueda cargar ningún archivo, ya que hacerlo podría provocar una recursividad infinita.

trans-unit.source: A list whose first element is the symbol :propertize says to process the mode line construct elt recursively, then add the text properties specified by props to the result. The argument props should consist of zero or more pairs text-propertyvalue. If elt is or produces a string with text properties, all the characters of that string should have the same properties, or else some of them might be removed by :propertize.
trans-unit.target: Una lista cuyo primer elemento es el símbolo :propertize dice que se procese la línea de modo construya elt de forma recursiva, luego agregue las propiedades de texto especificadas por props al resultado. Los props argumento deben constar de cero o más pares text-property value propiedad de texto . Si elt es o produce una cadena con propiedades de texto, todos los caracteres de esa cadena deben tener las mismas propiedades o, de lo contrario, algunos de ellos podrían ser eliminados por :propertize .

trans-unit.source: A list with no elements in it is the empty list; it is identical to the symbol nil. In other words, nil is both a symbol and a list.
trans-unit.target: Una lista sin elementos es la lista vacía ; es idéntico al símbolo nil . En otras palabras, nil es tanto un símbolo como una lista.

trans-unit.source: A local keymap can cancel a menu bar item made by the global keymap by rebinding the same fake function key with undefined as the binding. For example, this is how Dired suppresses the ‘
trans-unit.target: Un mapa de teclas local puede cancelar un elemento de la barra de menú creado por el mapa de teclas global volviendo a enlazar la misma tecla de función falsa con undefined como enlace. Por ejemplo, así es como Dired suprime el '

trans-unit.source: A loop that scans the buffer forwards, creating overlays, can run faster if you do (overlay-recenter (point-max)) first.
trans-unit.target: Un bucle que escanea el búfer hacia adelante, creando superposiciones, puede ejecutarse más rápido si lo hace (overlay-recenter (point-max)) primero.

trans-unit.source: A lot of code uses the old defadvice mechanism, which is largely made obsolete by the new advice-add, whose implementation and semantics is significantly simpler.
trans-unit.target: Una gran cantidad de código utiliza el antiguo mecanismo de defadvice , que en gran parte se ha vuelto obsoleto por el nuevo advice-add , cuya implementación y semántica es significativamente más simple.

trans-unit.source: A lower-level function for standardizing file names, which locate-user-emacs-file uses as a subroutine, is convert-standard-filename.
trans-unit.target: Una función de nivel inferior para estandarizar los nombres de archivo, que locate-user-emacs-file usa como subrutina, es convert-standard-filename .

trans-unit.source: A macro (see Macros) can also be marked obsolete with make-obsolete; this has the same effects as for a function. An alias for a function or macro can also be marked as obsolete; this makes the alias itself obsolete, not the function or macro which it resolves to.
trans-unit.target: Una macro (ver Macros ) también se puede marcar como obsoleta con make-obsolete ; esto tiene los mismos efectos que para una función. Un alias para una función o macro también se puede marcar como obsoleto; esto hace que el alias en sí sea obsoleto, no la función o macro a la que se resuelve.

trans-unit.source: A macro call looks just like a function call in that it is a list which starts with the name of the macro. The rest of the elements of the list are the arguments of the macro.
trans-unit.target: Una llamada de macro se parece a una llamada de funcin en que es una lista que comienza con el nombre de la macro.El resto de los elementos de la lista son los argumentos de la macro.

trans-unit.source: A magic autoload comment (often called an autoload cookie) consists of ‘
trans-unit.target: Un comentario mágico de carga automática (a menudo llamado cookie de carga automática ) consta de '

trans-unit.source: A major client of this is display-buffer-reuse-window, but all other action functions that try to reuse a window are affected as well. display-buffer-in-previous-window consults it when searching for a window that previously displayed the buffer on another frame.
trans-unit.target: Un cliente importante de esto es display-buffer-reuse-window , pero todas las demás funciones de acción que intentan reutilizar una ventana también se ven afectadas. display-buffer-in-previous-window lo consulta cuando busca una ventana que mostraba previamente el búfer en otro marco.

trans-unit.source: A major mode can also rebind the keys
trans-unit.target: Un modo principal tambin puede rebobinar las teclas

trans-unit.source: A margin display specification looks like ((margin right-margin) spec) or ((margin left-margin) spec). Here, spec is another display specification that says what to display in the margin. Typically it is a string of text to display, or an image descriptor.
trans-unit.target: A margin display specification looks like ((margin right-margin) spec) or ((margin left-margin) spec) . Here, spec is another display specification that says what to display in the margin. Typically it is a string of text to display, or an image descriptor.

trans-unit.source: A marker has three attributes: the marker position, the marker buffer, and the insertion type. The marker position is an integer that is equivalent (at a given time) to the marker as a position in that buffer. But the marker’s position value can change during the life of the marker, and often does. Insertion and deletion of text in the buffer relocate the marker. The idea is that a marker positioned between two characters remains between those two characters despite insertion and deletion elsewhere in the buffer. Relocation changes the integer equivalent of the marker.
trans-unit.target: A marker has three attributes: the marker position, the marker buffer, and the insertion type. The marker position is an integer that is equivalent (at a given time) to the marker as a position in that buffer. But the marker’s position value can change during the life of the marker, and often does. Insertion and deletion of text in the buffer relocate the marker. The idea is that a marker positioned between two characters remains between those two characters despite insertion and deletion elsewhere in the buffer. Relocation changes the integer equivalent of the marker.

trans-unit.source: A marker indicating the position of the end of the last output from this process inserted into the buffer. This is often but not always the end of the buffer.
trans-unit.target: Un marcador que indica la posicin del final de la ltima salida de este proceso insertado en el buffer.Este es a menudo,pero no siempre,el final del buffer.

trans-unit.source: A marker pointing to the position in the buffer that is the first character (in the logical order, see Bidirectional Display) displayed in the window.
trans-unit.target: A marker pointing to the position in the buffer that is the first character (in the logical order, see Bidirectional Display) displayed in the window.

trans-unit.source: A marker represents a buffer position to jump to.
trans-unit.target: Un marcador representa una posicin de amortiguacin a la que saltar.

trans-unit.source: A marker specifies a buffer and a position in that buffer. A marker can be used to represent a position in functions that require one, just as an integer could be used. In that case, the marker’s buffer is normally ignored. Of course, a marker used in this way usually points to a position in the buffer that the function operates on, but that is entirely the programmer’s responsibility. See Positions, for a complete description of positions.
trans-unit.target: A marker specifies a buffer and a position in that buffer. A marker can be used to represent a position in functions that require one, just as an integer could be used. In that case, the marker’s buffer is normally ignored. Of course, a marker used in this way usually points to a position in the buffer that the function operates on, but that is entirely the programmer’s responsibility. See Positions, for a complete description of positions.

trans-unit.source: A menu item can be a vector of three elements, [name callback enable]. name is the menu item name (a string). callback is a command to run, or an expression to evaluate, when the item is chosen. enable is an expression; if it evaluates to nil, the item is disabled for selection.
trans-unit.target: A menu item can be a vector of three elements, [name callback enable] . name is the menu item name (a string). callback is a command to run, or an expression to evaluate, when the item is chosen. enable is an expression; if it evaluates to nil , the item is disabled for selection.

trans-unit.source: A menu separator is a kind of menu item that doesn’t display any text—instead, it divides the menu into subparts with a horizontal line. A separator looks like this in the menu keymap:

trans-unit.source: A method of expanding an expression into another expression, more fundamental but less pretty.
trans-unit.target: Un mtodo para expandir una expresin en otra expresin,ms fundamental pero menos bonita.

trans-unit.source: A minibuffer window (see Minibuffer Windows) that is not alone on its frame does not have a parent window, so it strictly speaking is not part of its frame’s window tree. Nonetheless, it is a sibling window of the frame’s root window, and thus can be reached via window-next-sibling. Also, the function window-tree described at the end of this section lists the minibuffer window alongside the actual window tree.
trans-unit.target: A minibuffer window (see Minibuffer Windows) that is not alone on its frame does not have a parent window, so it strictly speaking is not part of its frame’s window tree. Nonetheless, it is a sibling window of the frame’s root window, and thus can be reached via window-next-sibling . Also, the function window-tree described at the end of this section lists the minibuffer window alongside the actual window tree.

trans-unit.source: A minibuffer window is never a candidate. A dedicated window (see Dedicated Windows) is never a candidate unless the optional argument dedicated is non-nil. The selected window is not a candidate if the optional argument not-selected is non-nil. If the optional argument not-selected is non-nil and the selected window is the only candidate, this function returns nil.
trans-unit.target: A minibuffer window is never a candidate. A dedicated window (see Dedicated Windows) is never a candidate unless the optional argument dedicated is non- nil . The selected window is not a candidate if the optional argument not-selected is non- nil . If the optional argument not-selected is non- nil and the selected window is the only candidate, this function returns nil .

trans-unit.source: A minor limitation of this feature, again because it targets symbols, is that only variables of dynamic scope may be watched. This poses little difficulty, since modifications to lexical variables can be discovered easily by inspecting the code within the scope of the variable (unlike dynamic variables, which can be modified by any code at all, see Variable Scoping).
trans-unit.target: A minor limitation of this feature, again because it targets symbols, is that only variables of dynamic scope may be watched. This poses little difficulty, since modifications to lexical variables can be discovered easily by inspecting the code within the scope of the variable (unlike dynamic variables, which can be modified by any code at all, see Variable Scoping).

trans-unit.source: A minor-mode function to call after visiting a file converted from this format. The function is called with one argument, the integer 1; that tells a minor-mode function to enable the mode.
trans-unit.target: Una funcin de modo menor para llamar despus de visitar un archivo convertido de este formato.La funcin se llama con un argumento,el nmero entero 1,que le dice a una funcin de modo menor que active el modo.

trans-unit.source: A mode line construct may be as simple as a fixed string of text, but it usually specifies how to combine fixed strings with variables’ values to construct the text. Many of these variables are themselves defined to have mode line constructs as their values.
trans-unit.target: A mode line construct may be as simple as a fixed string of text, but it usually specifies how to combine fixed strings with variables’ values to construct the text. Many of these variables are themselves defined to have mode line constructs as their values.

trans-unit.source: A more powerful operation is to mark the variable as automatically buffer-local by calling make-variable-buffer-local. You can think of this as making the variable local in all buffers, even those yet to be created. More precisely, the effect is that setting the variable automatically makes the variable local to the current buffer if it is not already so. All buffers start out by sharing the default value of the variable as usual, but setting the variable creates a buffer-local binding for the current buffer. The new value is stored in the buffer-local binding, leaving the default binding untouched. This means that the default value cannot be changed with setq in any buffer; the only way to change it is with setq-default.
trans-unit.target: A more powerful operation is to mark the variable as automatically buffer-local by calling make-variable-buffer-local . You can think of this as making the variable local in all buffers, even those yet to be created. More precisely, the effect is that setting the variable automatically makes the variable local to the current buffer if it is not already so. All buffers start out by sharing the default value of the variable as usual, but setting the variable creates a buffer-local binding for the current buffer. The new value is stored in the buffer-local binding, leaving the default binding untouched. This means that the default value cannot be changed with setq in any buffer; the only way to change it is with setq-default .

trans-unit.source: A package archive is simply a directory in which the package files, and associated files, are stored. If you want the archive to be reachable via HTTP, this directory must be accessible to a web server; See Archive Web Server.

trans-unit.target: A predicate—that is, a function of one argument that returns either nil or non- nil according to the argument. Using a predicate in the list says that objects for which the predicate returns non- nil are acceptable.

trans-unit.source: A primitive that is like a function but does not evaluate all of its arguments in the usual way. It may evaluate only some of the arguments, or may evaluate them in an unusual order, or several times. Examples include if, and, and while. See Special Forms.
trans-unit.target: A primitive that is like a function but does not evaluate all of its arguments in the usual way. It may evaluate only some of the arguments, or may evaluate them in an unusual order, or several times. Examples include if , and , and while . See Special Forms.

trans-unit.source: A process filter function is a function that receives the standard output from the associated process. All output from that process is passed to the filter. The default filter simply outputs directly to the process buffer.
trans-unit.target: A process filter function is a function that receives the standard output from the associated process. All output from that process is passed to the filter. The default filter simply outputs directly to the process buffer.

trans-unit.source: A process can (and usually does) have an associated buffer, which is an ordinary Emacs buffer that is used for two purposes: storing the output from the process, and deciding when to kill the process. You can also use the buffer to identify a process to operate on, since in normal practice only one process is associated with any given buffer. Many applications of processes also use the buffer for editing input to be sent to the process, but this is not built into Emacs Lisp.

You can also use the buffer to identify a process to operate on, since in normal practice only one process is associated with any given buffer. Many applications of processes also use the buffer for editing input to be sent to the process, but this is not built into Emacs Lisp.

In most cases, you should not use region-active-p, since if the region is empty it is often more appropriate to operate on point.

trans-unit.source: A regular expression which is used to recognize files represented in this format. If nil, the format is never applied automatically.
trans-unit.target: A regular expression which is used to recognize files represented in this format. If nil , the format is never applied automatically.

trans-unit.source: A repeating timer nominally ought to run every <var>repeat</var> seconds, but remember that any invocation of a timer can be late. Lateness of one repetition has no effect on the scheduled time of the next repetition. For instance, if Emacs is busy computing for long enough to cover three scheduled repetitions of the timer, and then starts to wait, it will immediately call the timer function three times in immediate succession (presuming no other timers trigger before or between them). If you want a timer to run again no less than <var>n</var> seconds after the last invocation, don’t use the <var>repeat</var> argument. Instead, the timer function should explicitly reschedule the timer.
trans-unit.target: A repeating timer nominally ought to run every <var>repeat</var> seconds, but remember that any invocation of a timer can be late. Lateness of one repetition has no effect on the scheduled time of the next repetition. For instance, if Emacs is busy computing for long enough to cover three scheduled repetitions of the timer, and then starts to wait, it will immediately call the timer function three times in immediate succession (presuming no other timers trigger before or between them). If you want a timer to run again no less than <var>n</var> seconds after the last invocation, don’t use the <var>repeat</var> argument. Instead, the timer function should explicitly reschedule the timer.

trans-unit.source: A search which fails may or may not alter the match data. In the current implementation, it does not, but we may change it in the future. Don’t try to rely on the value of the match data after a failing search.
trans-unit.target: A search which fails may or may not alter the match data. In the current implementation, it does not, but we may change it in the future. Don’t try to rely on the value of the match data after a failing search.

trans-unit.source: A self-evaluating form yields a value that becomes part of the program, and you should not try to modify it via setcar, aset or similar operations. The Lisp interpreter might unify the constants yielded by your program’s self-evaluating forms, so that these constants might share structure. See Mutability.
trans-unit.target: A self-evaluating form yields a value that becomes part of the program, and you should not try to modify it via setcar , aset or similar operations. The Lisp interpreter might unify the constants yielded by your program’s self-evaluating forms, so that these constants might share structure. See Mutability.

trans-unit.source: A sentinel runs only while Emacs is waiting (e.g., for terminal input, or for time to elapse, or for process output). This avoids the timing errors that could result from running sentinels at random places in the middle of other Lisp programs. A program can wait, so that sentinels will run, by calling sit-for or sleep-for (see Waiting), or accept-process-output (see Accepting Output). Emacs also allows sentinels to run when the command loop is reading input. delete-process calls the sentinel when it terminates a running process.
trans-unit.target: A sentinel runs only while Emacs is waiting (e.g., for terminal input, or for time to elapse, or for process output). This avoids the timing errors that could result from running sentinels at random places in the middle of other Lisp programs. A program can wait, so that sentinels will run, by calling sit-for or sleep-for (see Waiting), or accept-process-output (see Accepting Output). Emacs also allows sentinels to run when the command loop is reading input. delete-process calls the sentinel when it terminates a running process.

trans-unit.source: A sentinel that writes the output into the buffer of the process should check whether the buffer is still alive. If it tries to insert into a dead buffer, it will get an error. If the buffer is dead, (buffer-name (process-buffer process)) returns nil.
trans-unit.target: A sentinel that writes the output into the buffer of the process should check whether the buffer is still alive. If it tries to insert into a dead buffer, it will get an error. If the buffer is dead, (buffer-name (process-buffer process)) returns nil .

trans-unit.source: A serial connection is represented by a process object, which can be used in a similar way to a subprocess or network process. You can send and receive data, and configure the serial port. A serial process object has no process ID, however, and you can’t send signals to it, and the status codes are different from other types of processes. delete-process on the process object or kill-buffer on the process buffer close the connection, but this does not affect the device connected to the serial port.
trans-unit.target: A serial connection is represented by a process object, which can be used in a similar way to a subprocess or network process. You can send and receive data, and configure the serial port. A serial process object has no process ID, however, and you can’t send signals to it, and the status codes are different from other types of processes. delete-process on the process object or kill-buffer on the process buffer close the connection, but this does not affect the device connected to the serial port.

trans-unit.source: A short-cut function is useful in modes such as C mode and Lisp mode, where the indent-line-function must scan from the beginning of the function definition: applying it to each line would be quadratic in time. The short cut can update the scan information as it moves through the lines indenting them; this takes linear time. In a mode where indenting a line individually is fast, there is no need for a short cut.

The short cut can update the scan information as it moves through the lines indenting them; this takes linear time. In a mode where indenting a line individually is fast, there is no need for a short cut.

trans-unit.source: A simple way to find out which variables need a variable definition is to byte-compile the source file. See Byte Compilation. If a non-special variable is used outside of a let form, the byte-compiler will warn about reference or assignment to a free variable. If a non-special variable is bound but not used within a let form, the byte-compiler will warn about an unused lexical variable. The byte-compiler will also issue a warning if you use a special variable as a function argument.
trans-unit.target: Una forma sencilla de averiguar qué variables necesitan una definición de variable es compilar en bytes el archivo fuente. Consulte Compilación de bytes . Si se usa una variable no especial fuera de una forma let , el compilador de bytes advertirá sobre la referencia o asignación a una variable libre. Si una variable no especial está vinculada pero no se usa dentro de una forma let , el compilador de bytes advertirá sobre una variable léxica no utilizada. El compilador de bytes también emitirá una advertencia si usa una variable especial como argumento de función.

trans-unit.source: A single keymap directly specifies definitions for individual events. When a key sequence consists of a single event, its binding in a keymap is the keymap’s definition for that event. The binding of a longer key sequence is found by an iterative process: first find the definition of the first event (which must itself be a keymap); then find the second event’s definition in that keymap, and so on until all the events in the key sequence have been processed.
trans-unit.target: Un único mapa de teclas especifica directamente las definiciones para eventos individuales. Cuando una secuencia de teclas consta de un solo evento, su enlace en un mapa de teclas es la definición del mapa de teclas para ese evento. La unión de una secuencia de teclas más larga se encuentra mediante un proceso iterativo: primero busque la definición del primer evento (que debe ser en sí mismo un mapa de teclas); luego busque la definición del segundo evento en ese mapa de teclas, y así sucesivamente hasta que se hayan procesado todos los eventos de la secuencia de teclas.
